author: {'steamid': '76561197961314453', 'num_games_owned': 691, 'num_reviews': 30, 'playtime_forever': 824, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 824, 'last_played': 1412569666}
review:
I don't usually play those kinds of games, I usually just play them for 5 minutes and drop them, but this is probably the slickest looking, well-polished tower defense game I've seen, which was what drew me into it and contributed to my playing it all the way through. And killing pesky humans! Who wouldn't jump at the chance?

The game is about how to manage your income and optimally allocate turrets. It takes a while to figure out which technologies/turrets work best in what situations. Eventually you find and set up some pretty powerful turret combos. The basic "blaster" turret is extremely powerful and durable when fully upgraded. I didn't think the booster turret (the one that doesn't shoot and only supports other turrets) was worth it, it took up a spot and didn't really do much, and the enemies would usually go for that first for some dumb reason.

The pause feature is pretty huge. It makes any turret setup or tactic manageable to execute. It really took the steam out of the later levels. Maybe that is the point? If you don't ever use pause to play let me know how it goes.

Each turret can have a special ability, and you get to manage all that and passive bonuses in a tech tree. I found that the energy bonuses and the sniper ability (which increases range of turrets) were very, very powerful. It's the only way to get a decent number of turrets firing on each enemy, which makes some of the boss-type encounters into a joke. I thought it was fun to manage all the angles and set up spots where I'd set of bunch of turrets to sniper, so that the big tanks would get crushed.

author: {'steamid': '76561197971647245', 'num_games_owned': 2721, 'num_reviews': 44, 'playtime_forever': 1395, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 416, 'last_played': 1618768086}
review:
This TD game is among the good ones. I don't think this is as good as the original anomaly games, since those games gave you more tactical options. But still, this game gives a great TD experience compared to many other TDs.
And please, don't take it as yet another tower defence. It is awesome, especially if you played the first 2 Anomaly games.

04.18.2021:
Recently I have decided to finish all levels on hard and based on this experience I change my recommendation.
On hard, many levels are so f***ing frustrating. You have to try different tactics dozens of time because at some point you realize that your tactics worth nothing for a particular wave and you loose most of your towers. It is especially frustrating when the level has like 40 waves and you have to start over. The worst thing is that any time you fail a wave you have to restart the level from the very first wave. Very fun when you have to go through 10, 20 or even 30 waves again just to realize that your new tactic fails again.

DO NOT BUY THIS GAME!

author: {'steamid': '76561197993109243', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 235, 'playtime_forever': 588, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 570, 'last_played': 1681842505}
review:
Meh. It's Tower Defense. It's not bad, but there's really nothing innovative or unique about it. It's a good addition to the series, but not really a notable title in the genre. The interesting thing about Anomaly is that it was reverse TD. You were the attacking mobs and you had to survive the tower defense. That was an interesting twist on the old game that made it more interesting.

Anomaly Defenders is just straight TD with very little to make it interesting. Like I said, it's not a bad game. If you really need to have the full set, I don't think you'll be disapponted with Anomaly 3. If you're looking for a new, different TD game, this isn't it. Try Sanctum 2 or Defense Grid (nothing necessarily "interesting" about DG either, it's just a very solid TD, and in my opinion better than AD).

I keep saying this isn't a bad game, and it really isn't. But due to the fact that it's essentially just an Anomaly skin on top of [any TD game ever], I can't give it a thumbs up. It pains me to give it a thumbs down. I wish I could give it "no thumbs," but I have to choose.

If somebody I don't know asks me "should I get Anomay Defenders?" my answer is no. It's a non-event in the history of Tower Defense. If you can get it on the cheap (like I did in a recent Humble Bundle), do it.

If PaulC asks me "should I get Anomaly Defenders?" my answer is yes. It's a good, solid TD that's different enough from Defense Grid that I think you'll enjoy it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198027195149', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 78, 'playtime_forever': 505, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 505, 'last_played': 1412149852}
review:
Finally, an awesome TD game! Went through so many duds after Field runners 2, then finally stumbled across this game. I figured I would give it a try and im glad I did. Great maps, nice upgrade table, great music and sound. This game is the ideal     TD game. Usually micromanaging aggrivates me, but this games seems to mesh the mircromanaging aspect in so well, I hardly noticed I was doing it! I give this a solid 9/10!

I will say if you are into creating your own mazes/paths, you won't find that here. Just good ol' fashion tower defense! Correction, you can make enemies take different paths by adding a specific building to different paths. So in a way you can alter the path of the baddies. Hope this helps!

author: {'steamid': '76561198035508167', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 25, 'playtime_forever': 1363, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1363, 'last_played': 1412001799}
review:
I have a somewhat unhealthy addiction to Anomaly games, so this review [i]maaaaay[/i] be a little biased. Especially more so seeing as I can safely say this is my favourite entry in the series. The previous three Anomaly games were purely tower offense oriented where the player would roll out with a convoy of vehicles and clear certain checkpoints, rescue some scientists, or travel from A to B. Anomaly Defenders moves away from this to a tower defence perspective and does this to exceptional standards.

[b]STORY[/b]
After years of war and suffering at the hands of alien torment, the human fleet is now ready to carry out its own invasion against a race that once threatened its very existence. The Commander from the first three Anomaly games decides he no longer wishes to take part in the genocide that would soon follow, and therefore makes the hard call of commanding the alien units in defending escape pods to off-planet. And that's where [i]YOU[/i] come in.

[b]GAMEPLAY[/b]
The game is aimed at both casual and hardcore tower defence strategist with elements of simplicity and complexity involved. Familiarising yourself with the types of enemy units and propelling the right towers to dispatch those tanks is crucial in understanding the balance. You have your basic selection of various tower units with their respective upgrades. Towers are placed on spawning hotspots with each tower consisting of three possible upgrades. You also have perks and functions in your arsenal to add an extra layer of buff to tower durability and longevity, as well as influcing your rate of income. Maps vary with some symmetry and linear designs, but all fairly challenging as the missions and difficulty progress. The variety in units also help in the challenge factor as you will strive to find ways to gain the upper hand against certain unit types.

You should expect to pump out anywhere between 4 to 30 hours worth of playtime depending on how you play the game. If, like me, you plan on completing everything then you will find yourself spending anywhere between the 20-30 hour mark trying to complete the game on easy, normal and hard difficulties. Alternatively a single run should take anywhere between 4-7 hours depending on how familiar you are with tower defence games. Unfortunately campaign is the only game mode in Anomaly Defenders and it only spans 24 missions. There really isn't a great deal of replay value unless you wish to mix and match upgrades in the technology tree. Some sort of map creator/sharing service would have been a nice addition.

[b]GRAPHICS & AUDIO[/b]
Graphically the game is onpar with past Anomaly games. Looks great and runs well without falter. You will encounter various environmental conditions whether that be lightning storm or meteorite showers which adds to the level of detail. One complaint I do have is that for every kill there is a flash of light. This may not seem like a big deal, but imagine killing 6 units within 10 seconds. Your screen will be freaking out. If you have any issues with flashing images due to medical conditions, I would recommend you steer clear of this game.

For the first time in an Anomaly game I actually enjoyed listening to the announcer in the background. Voice acting is usually quite poor, but they seemed to have nailed it on this. The soundtrack only has four tracks but they are really good. I found the game to be that much more exciting listening to the exhilerating music pounding away in the background. It got the job done and that's all that matters.

[b]OVERALL[/b]
A fantastic final entry in the Anomaly series and one that should definitely be checked out by tower defence fans.

[u][b]PROS[/b][/u]
+Fantastic way to end the series. Full on tower defence.
+Technology tree expands on gameplay.
+24 action packed missions - [i]bumped to 72 if achievement hunting[/i].
+Visually looks stunning.
+Soundtrack is excellent.

[u][b]CONS[/b][/u]
-Screen flash for every kill.
-No additional game modes to add replayability other than difficulty settings.

author: {'steamid': '76561198040533651', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 1199, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 538, 'last_played': 1583563759}
review: I truly enjoyed this game.  I usually don't like tower defense games very much, but this one seems to be an exception.  I found the strategy element to be quite good especially at higher difficulties.  However if what you want is a story this is not the game for you.  Other than 2 short (~15 second) videos there is no story at all.  Not even short the short text based level intro conversations that are often used to set the mood. Other than a location name and a description of the level you are given no background whatsoever.  Usually I, myself, would have problems with enjoying a game with no story, but the gameplay made me more forgiving.

author: {'steamid': '76561197992674721', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 568, 'playtime_forever': 195, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 132, 'last_played': 1493817072}
review:
In this sequel to the famous Anomaly series, you defend, you do not attack. So basically this became a tower defense-like game. And it's pure awesomness, graphics are stellar, level design fabolous, sound effects and music also.

I recommend strongly.

review:
Als Fan von Defense Grid f√ºhle ich mich gleich wohl und habe dennoch frisches Gameplay. Der Forschungsbaum und die M√∂glichkeiten der Aufr√ºstung machen Anomaly Defenders so interessant. Die gebauten Tower k√∂nnen Schaden nehmen und m√ºssen nicht nur in Stand gehalten werden, es muss sp√§ter auch regelm√§ssig mit speziellen Upgrades aktiv und proaktiv unterst√ºtzt werden, das macht das Gameplay dynamisch - f√ºr DG Fans wie mich, ist AD ein 'bewegliches' DG mit massig Optionen.

Anomaly Defenders bekommt von mir eine klare Kaufempfehlung: mit dem Tower-Defense Game hab nicht nur ich noch einige dutzend Stunden kommendes Gameplay zu erwarten. Dazu als SteamPlay und mit Linux-Port. Nice Work, nice Game, Ready Player 1? Start!

author: {'steamid': '76561197969417125', 'num_games_owned': 527, 'num_reviews': 378, 'playtime_forever': 1003, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 475, 'last_played': 1421934140}
review:
Anomaly Defenders is the third game in the Anomaly series. In the previous games the player controlled Human forces in a unique "tower offence" mode. Defenders changes the format, and now the player controls the aliens in a more traditional tower defence mode. The aliens are fleeing their homeworld, and you need to prevent the Humans from destroying spaceship launchpads. The main twist compared to other TD games that I've played, is that the Humans can shoot your towers, instead of just ignoring them.

As with most TD games, you can build and upgrade various types of towers using carusarum (effectively money). Carusarum is earned by killing enemy units and you can also build harvester towers to extract carusarum from specific points on the map. You can also use special abilities on your towers, such as repair, rage (damage buff), sniper (range buff) and shield (reduce damage). These abilities cost energy, which is also gained from killing enemies.

There is a tech tree which allows you to spend points on upgrading the strength of your towers and abilities, improve your economy through improved efficiency of harvesters and better cost of buying/selling towers, and increase energy storage. You gain tech points for completing maps based on score and difficulty, and spend them between missions.

I wouldn't say there is a great variety in towers or enemy units. Most are as seen in the previous games, I think the only new enemies are the aircraft. A couple of maps have environmental effects, such as electromagnetic storms and falling debris, which can disable/damage your towers and enemy units.

I played on the middle of three difficulty levels, and only lost one of the 24 maps, but the second half of the game does get quite frantic. I can imagine the top difficulty could be quite challenging. I think my previous experience with the franchise helped me to quickly figure out the best placement for each type of tower. Later map layouts become fairly complex, with enemies attacking simultaneously along multiple ground and air paths. You can influence the enemy path with your harvesters, because the Humans will try to attack those before your launchpad.

The story is non-existent, which is disappointing. The previous games' stories weren't amazing but at least they made an effort. I also find it strange that the Humans don't have a commander (the player unit in previous games). I guess it might have been difficult to program the AI controlling him, but it doesn't really make sense based on the established series lore. The Human forces would get annihilated quickly in the previous games without the commander, so why attack now without him?

The music is fantastic and I didn't experience any bugs. There are no mid mission checkpoints, which means if you lose a map (or crash for any reason) its back to the start. Each map should only take around 20 minutes though. I finished the campaign in 8 hours which is fine relative to the low purchase price.

Overall, if you like tower defence and have a few hours available, this is worth checking out.

author: {'steamid': '76561198037410959', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 856, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 668, 'last_played': 1550008221}
review: Really well-made tower defense game. If you liked Anomaly: Warzone Earth, Anomaly Korea adn Anomaly 2, you should give a chance Anomaly Defenders, because it is a fresh view in the series.

author: {'steamid': '76561197969018797', 'num_games_owned': 2044, 'num_reviews': 39, 'playtime_forever': 1140, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1140, 'last_played': 1404346917}
review:
I love Tower Defense games! The first two Anomaly games were unique as they did a unique twist and had you controlling the enemy wave instead with the goal of destroying towers and getting to the goal. Not only that, but you had a story-driven campaign and you could easily see the production values that went into those games. The 2nd game even had two player co-op. It was just getting better and better...

When I realized Anomaly Defenders came out, I immediately purchased it. Within the first 5 minutes of playing, I was disappointed greatly. The last game did a complete 180 and you now control the alien towers. So just a generic tower defense game... great. This is even further solidified that it lacks any story-driven campaign and you're not sure why you should care about these aliens. The Technology Tree of upgrading towers and unlocking new skills/passives is cool, but it doesn't make the gameplay any less mundane. I'm currently on Mission 21 of 24 and slowly forcing myself to finish it and get it over with. I even noticed some of the missions are re-hashes of older ones.

Thanks for ruining the franchise 11 bit studios!

review:

Anomaly Defenders est un jeu d√©velopp√© et √©dit√© par les studios 11bit. Il s‚Äôagit d‚Äôun Tower Defense qui fait suite historiquement parlant √† Anomaly : Warzone Hearth et Anomaly 2.

Cette fois le joueur n‚Äôest plus dans la peau des humains qui essayent tant bien que mal de r√©cup√©rer leur plan√®te attaqu√©e par les aliens mais bien dans celle de ces derniers. En effet cette fois-ci ce sont les humains qui attaquent les aliens!

Alors qu‚Äôavec les pr√©c√©dents volets nous √©tions dans un type de Tower Defense invers√© o√π nous ne contr√¥lions pas les tours ni leur disposition mais les unit√©s en les faisant avancer d‚Äôun point A √† un point B, ici nous sommes dans un Tower Defense des plus classiques. Vous interpr√©tez donc les aliens avec leurs tours de d√©fense et leur technologie.


[b]Un tower-defense-re-invers√© ?[/b]


Alors que la s√©rie Anomaly Defenders nous avait habitu√© √† un nouveau concept de Tower Defense, celle-ci ayant d√©cid√©e de revenir aux origines du genre, le joueur risque d‚Äô√™tre un peu d√©√ßu. Comportant vingt quatre niveaux avec trois modes de difficult√©s, facile, normal et difficile, le jeu s‚Äôav√®re assez court si vous d√©cidez de ne le finir qu‚Äôen un seul mode de jeu. Vous avez donc tout int√©r√™t √† recommencer tous les niveaux et les terminer en variant les modes.

En achevant un niveau vous obtiendrez des points de Technologies que vous pourrez d√©penser dans l‚Äôarbre des Technologies. Obtenant d‚Äôavantage de points en effectuant les niveaux en difficult√© avanc√©e, le joueur sera toujours tent√© d‚Äôen venir √† bout afin de d√©bloquer un maximum de technologies pour l‚Äôaider √† avancer dans sa campagne. Les technologies d√©bloquent divers bonus et capacit√©s pour vos tours de d√©fense.

Comportant au total huit tours dont une tour de r√©colte, chaque tour a ses propres caract√©ristiques d‚Äôattaque et de d√©fense et sera plus ou moins efficace selon l‚Äôennemi rencontr√©.
L‚Äôarbre des technologies permet d‚Äôaugmenter leur niveau, c‚Äôest gr√¢ce √† lui qu‚Äôen jeu vous pourrez faire √©voluer vos tours jusqu‚Äôaux niveaux maximums. Par ailleurs nous retrouvons la particularit√© du gameplay rencontr√©e dans les anciens opus consistant √† disposer des capacit√©s utilisables sur vos tours comme le bouclier, l‚Äôauto r√©g√©n√©ration ou encore le mode rage permettant de donner un boost d‚Äôattaque √† celles-ci.


[b]Du Tower Defense classique √† la sauce Anomaly ![/b]


Pour le gameplay cela reste classique √† un tower defense, vous avez des emplacements pr√©d√©finis sur la carte pour poser vos tours. Certaines tours plus grosses que d‚Äôautres prendront plus de place et vous vous rendrez vite compte que le placement est un atout strat√©gique indispensable!

Vous disposerez du Carusaurum (le minerai qui permet aux aliens de poser les tours et de les faire √©voluer) en tuant des humains ou en les r√©coltant avec la tour ad√©quate. Une bonne gestion de celui-ci est primordiale pour contenir les vagues d‚Äôennemis qui peuvent s‚Äôenchainer parfois sans discontinuer selon le niveau. En tuant les unit√©s ennemies, non seulement vous remporterez du minerai mais vous ramasserez √©galement de l‚Äôenergy n√©cessaire √† l‚Äôutilisation de vos capacit√©s (cit√©es un peu plus haut) sur vos tours. Il est √©galement indispensable de g√©rer cette ressource correctement si vous souhaitez emp√™cher la destruction de vos tours ou faire face √† une attaque massive de troupes ennemies sur votre tour de lancement qui doit absolument rester debout pour √©viter le Game Over.

Une fois les techniques de jeu maitris√©es, il est int√©ressant de recommencer les niveaux pour les terminer avec un maximum de points, vous permettant de comparer vos scores avec vos amis ou les autres joueurs du monde. Par contre, il n‚Äôy a plus de mode multijoueurs comme dans Anomaly 2.

On notera √©galement que les humains r√©agissent de la m√™me mani√®re que dans les anciens jeux avec des voies de passage diff√©rentes sur les cartes, for√ßant donc le joueur √† poser de mani√®re strat√©gique ses tours pour parer √† toute √©ventualit√©. Attention √©galement aux boss qui, s‚Äôils ne sont pas g√©r√©s correctement, peuvent faire de gros d√©g√¢ts sur les tours et rendre leurs attaques totalement inoffensives.


[b]Des musiques √©piques ![/b]


Graphiquement r√©ussi, Anomaly Defenders n‚Äôaura pas de mal √† vous faire plonger dans son univers spatial. Malgr√© des effets visuels aboutis lors des attaques humaines ou sur les cartes elles-m√™mes on regrettera tout de m√™me la similitude graphique des niveaux. Cependant rappelons qu‚Äôil est assez compliqu√© d‚Äôapporter des √©l√©ment nouveaux √† son style d√©j√† bien √©tabli au cours des pr√©c√©dents opus.

Bien que les musiques ne soient pas nombreuses elles restent n√©anmoins √©piques et vous serez imm√©diatement dans le bain pr√™t affronter les menaces ennemies. Vraiment r√©ussie la bande-son est digne des plus grands jeux!


[b]Alors verdict ?[/b]


En conclusion Anomaly Defenders est un tr√®s bon Tower Defense accessible aussi bien aux joueurs d√©butants qu‚Äôaux hardcore gamers qui voudront obtenir les meilleures stats sur tous les niveaux de difficult√©s. Avec un syst√®me de jeu assez classique et sans r√©elles nouveaut√©s, la force de la s√©rie Anomaly repose sur son gameplay et son univers. Anomaly Defenders vaut largement ses 9.99‚Ç¨ mais nous attendons tout de m√™me des DLC histoire d‚Äôallonger sa dur√©e de vie. Notons que le jeu est disponible sur Windows, Mac et Linux.

author: {'steamid': '76561197979084213', 'num_games_owned': 4500, 'num_reviews': 1010, 'playtime_forever': 264, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 264, 'last_played': 1402560864}
review:
+ Graphics
+ Tech tree
+ Challenging
+ Plenty of maps
+ Energy bar is an interesting concept and requires more tactical placement of your towers

+/- Some of the towers look too similar, can be confusing if there's a lot of action going on
+/- Clicking on energy orbs doesn't always register properly

- Can be a bit hectic during the bigger battles
- Adds nothing truly new to the tower defense formula

[Rating: 78/100]

author: {'steamid': '76561197974002194', 'num_games_owned': 1646, 'num_reviews': 237, 'playtime_forever': 118, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 118, 'last_played': 1403715898}
review:
J'ai fini Anomaly et Anomaly 2. Est-ce que cet opus va me plaire ? 
Et bien, c'est peu probable malheureusement, je m'explique : 

Dans Anomaly, 11bitstudios renversait brillamment le Tower Defense en Tower Offense, √ßa marchait et on avait m√™me droit √† un sc√©nar' qui ne g√¢chait rien. 
Dans le 2, une ind√©niable profondeur tactique √©tait affirm√©e, les graphismes atteignaient une vraie maturit√© et on pouvait continuer √† comprendre pourquoi au juste on d√©zinguait des tours aliens. C'√©tait merveilleux, vraiment je les ai aim√©. Aujourd'hui retour aux fondamentaux, Tower Defense - Ok, tr√®s bien. L'univers d'Anomaly est-il l√†? Oui, mais en demi-teinte, rien de comparable avec ce que les Devs nous ont donn√© avant. Le look est respect√©, mais honn√™tement on jurerait un prototype, tr√®s peu fouill√© et pas de r√©elle trame en fond. Les composantes principales sont l√† - FIN. Donc, d√©ception artistique, on revient √† quelque chose de moins stimulant que le 2. C√¥t√© gameplay, c'est plus que tr√®s ordinaire : loin, tr√®s loin de l'intensit√© tactique du 2 o√π l'on devait g√©rer la vitesse du jeu, la position de son commandant, le chemin, l'ordre de ses v√©hicules et j'en passe. 

Au final, une coquille fort creuse, qui ne m'a pas rappel√© aux bons souvenirs de la s√©rie. Mais, secr√®tement, je continue d'esp√©r√© un tower offense Anomaly 3, un jour !

author: {'steamid': '76561197969384637', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 226, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 146, 'last_played': 1402826652}
review: On a scale of 1 to 10, I'm leaning towards a 6.5. It's certainly a polished game - the sound and graphics are pretty appealing. It just doesn't feel like there's a lot of variability to the play style, even with the tech tree. It feels like it's a TD game "on rails". I'm not sure I would recommend it for the ~$10 price, but on sale it would worth a few hours of play time.

author: {'steamid': '76561198078282707', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 1046, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1021, 'last_played': 1402413790}
review:
11 bit is at it again, and once more, they've built a brilliant game.
Following on the anomaly series, now is your turn to be on the defensive and fight the human scum!
I'm a bit over halfway on the missions, went back and replayed a few of the first ones on hard, using the upgrades I've got later on and to extract the last few tech points needed to grow the tech tree.
I've played a few tower defense games and so far, this one is the most satisfying, it takes not only strategic planning, but you also have to micro manage your towers, healing, upgrading and using their special abilities, while making sure you don't run out of the two resources, carosaurum to build and upgrade, and energy to deploy said abilities.
I hope this one not the be the end of the saga, they've got a great game here.

author: {'steamid': '76561198004087750', 'num_games_owned': 543, 'num_reviews': 82, 'playtime_forever': 648, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 648, 'last_played': 1401642426}
review:
11 bit studios are at it again and this time, they switched the roles back to the classic defense in the gameplay from the previous Anomaly. They definitely made a good job out there and I hope they continue to expand their series and perhaps into something that next-gen players will look forward to...

This game was never a waste, the whole story of Anomaly was worth it, even their in-game music blending was superb. Players out there, I would definitely recommend this game. Don't think twice anymore.

author: {'steamid': '76561198007185785', 'num_games_owned': 597, 'num_reviews': 22, 'playtime_forever': 382, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 265, 'last_played': 1401831238}
review:
So long I'm really enjoying this game. What you get:
- 24 missions
- tower defense where you not only need to destroy enemy units - these units fight back, so you often must be really carefull and do some micro-manage
- cool graphics! game looks really great
- tech tree you must invest into to get new towers, powers and buffs; technologies you pick up have real influence on gameplay
- different difficulty levels - and medium is not too easy :)

I didn't encounter any bugs or issues so far and game works fine on my PC, which is little outdated now (Core 2 Duo, 4 GB RAM, mediocre graphic card).

author: {'steamid': '76561198011760729', 'num_games_owned': 440, 'num_reviews': 22, 'playtime_forever': 148, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 148, 'last_played': 1401467915}
review:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=JsUmst7LWXI

Anomaly Defenders Review - http://www.heavenforgamers.com/anomaly-defenders-review
 
Anomaly Defenders is latest title in Anomaly series. The original idea of Tower Offense as sub-genre to control humans in battles against alien invaders is now completely opposite. In fact, now you are protector of alien homeworld while counterattack is underway. Defend the planet from humans in old fashion way..its time for tower defense !

There are various titles in Tower Defense genre, they are usually addictive for most of the people but we must admit fact that they are offering rather passive experiance. Anomaly Defenders on the other side brings you experiance where you need to act fast and perhaps be more aggresive then usually. In fact, people scums which are trying to destroy our planet this time will try to be annoying since beside armor and health they will attack and try to breach through your defense so therefor you will need to plan your strategy and have in mind one step ahead, which also prevents your towers to became overpowered.

Your main goal is ofcourse to defend in this case launchpads. Each time when you start campaign you will be able to build abilities in tech-tree for your needs to proced through 24 missions. These are RPG elements which is in fact suprising. At the start of every mission you will get good amount of carusarium which will provides you ability to build towers on tower blocks which are ultimately and only places where you can build them. There are varius sizes of towers with different range for attacks so you will need to choose wisely.

Some missions will have only one entrance point while some will have more including even couple ways through level to get their dirty hands on your launchpad. There are squads or more likely known as waves in which enemy units will appear. By destroying enemy units you will be getting carusarium and energy points where you need to click on bubles during fights to collect points but be careful because by collecting them when you are on maximum limit you will just throw them away, be patient and wait good opportunity . Energy points are for special functions as repair your tower, make them go berserk, sacrifice them in explosions to harm those nasty humans or perhaps use shield for your tower or even throw EMP explosion and disable enemy weapons for limited time.

Tech tree will give you abilities to upgrade towers on higher levels and unlock extra features. Interesting side of this game that you will actually need to use your brain little bit more, in fact healing towers is based on time limit so healing them while enemies attacks you will most likely ignore incoming damage and sometimes even heal to maximum health, if you are without energy points to keep them in life there is always option to sell tower and build another one perhaps somewhere further and closer to your touchpad especially if you are fighting through last wave and humans are going strong.

There is option to pause and speedup game if you are tired of waiting but most of the time you will preffer slower gameplay due to those options and strategies. Some areas are full with incoming asteroids with random impact areas, as they will help you sometimes most of the time they will damage your towers but you are going to be notified and get counter with couple seconds before impact so that you can actually upgrade either heal tower on time.

Beside all that action package which you will get in this game there is and passive side. By unlocking tech-tree you will get harvesters. Those are passive towers without ability to attack but in case that you build them on reserved spots you will be getting carusarium by every couple seconds, amount of carusarium is limited so as every other unit in this game, upgrade will be required. Sometimes by building those harvesters you will lure enemies to go other way around and perhaps suprise them.Building towers behind some objects in fact will act as suprising element and it will get less damage due to non-visibility to enemy units.

Anomaly Defenders has a bright shiny palette, in specific sci-fi tone. The level design and the graphics will get your attention yet one never overpowers or detracts from the other. Levels were created with passion, and there is a good amount of variance between them, which keeps the game visually interesting. Music and sound effects are actually suprisingly well done so it will bring you only more pleasure to relax and enjoy in upcoming challenges.

Despite fact that there are countless tower defense games this one just feels different. It‚Äôs an unique experiance with really well covered all aspects in the game for only 10 dollars available on Steam, Mac and Linux.

author: {'steamid': '76561198058093092', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 95, 'playtime_forever': 598, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 474, 'last_played': 1403428198}
review:
Anomaly Defenders is a nice little game. I've played through 7 of the 24 levels, all on Medium difficulty (there is also Easy and Hard). Can't really compare it to other full-fledged TD games since I am not much of a fan of the genre, but all I can say is that it is a good TD representation of the Anomaly series.

The towers and the human units would be familiar if you've played the previous Anomaly games. Defenders builds upon that, and you have abilities as well (similar to the previous games, again). You can upgrade units, and sell them on the fly. There is a skill tree too that uses points you accumulate after every successful mission, where you have some amount of freedom to chart your way forward. 

One nice feature is that you can pause the game to strategize, and also build towers, apply abilities and upgrade all while the game is paused...too many TD games are just so action-packed you don't have time to think at all.. But that's not the case here. 

It's kind of obvious Anomaly Defenders had less work put into it compared to Anomaly 2 judging by the graphics and the lack of story, but the good thing is the gameplay doesn't seem to have been truncated and the price is at least reflective of the smaller effort put into the game. 24 levels seem quite a bit, and you can replay earlier levels on harder difficulties when you've unlocked better upgrades in the skill tree.

Overall, if you were a fan of the Anomaly games prior to this, I'd recommend Anomaly Defenders. Decent amount of content, strong gameplay (even if it starts off too easily) and a reasonable price-tag.
